author: Madeleine van Niekerk
title: Bonds follow rand weaker ahead of local policy statement | Markets
text:
Picture: THINKSTOCK Related articles Stocks slip as earnings, Chinese weakness weigh Rand extends losses following CPI data Gold retains gains near $1,175 on sluggish dollar SOUTH African bonds were softer at midday on Wednesday in line with a weaker rand ahead of Finance Minister Nhlanhla Nene’s Medium Term Budget Policy Statement in the afternoon.
Unchanged local September inflation data released on Wednesday morning had little affect on the bond market.
Annual consumer price inflation was 4.6% in September 2015, unchanged from August 2015, Statistics SA data showed on Wednesday.
The figure was in line with the consensus forecast.
At 11.36am, the benchmark R186 bond was bid at 8.295% and offered at 8.285% from Tuesday’s close of 8.250%.
The middle-dated R207 was bid at 7.705% and offered at 7.665% from its previous close of 7.655%.
Finance Minister Nene is due to table the Medium Term Budget Policy Statement (MTBPS) at around 2pm with SA at one of its most difficult fiscal junctures.
Markets will be looking to see if the MTBPS can continue to deliver on the goal of fiscal consolidation given the challenging backdrop since the tabling of the 2015/16 Budget in February, Barclays Research analysts said in a note.
The analysts expect the Finance Minister to present a lower growth forecast for this fiscal year.
Against this, Barclays project a revenue shortfall of about R14.5bn, driven mainly by weaker corporate tax receipts, causing the main budget deficit to miss its target by 0.4% of gross domestic product.
